There is an implicit assumption that I think gets missed when talking about vectors; they are logical arguments. When you construct systems of equations, you are implying that they are able to be operated on, and that row/column switching and other algebraic properties apply, just as they apply in logic or argumentation. A vector, the composition of scalars, then carries with it the assumption that those scalars have a quantifiable relation, including the identity for R1, etc.

If you treat linear algebra like truth tables in deductive logic, the whole endeavor becomes way more interesting imo

Mathematics is merely the top level abstraction of reality from which new instances of reality can be derived.

It is one end of a reciprocal process of ignorance (chaos) observation (imagination) leading to understanding (order) leading to creation (reality) leading to observation.

DNA is an early version of this process before neurons superseded it.

So “space” really just means the realm of possibilities for a given system whether it be a purely abstract mathematical system or the evolution of genetic traits and mnemtic concepts. This “space” consists of “states”, their “relationships”, and the change from one state to another.

The most direct application is the simulation of reality which brains have been doing for eons.

Students always find it weird to think of functions as vectors at first, but really any vector you can think of is a function. Lists of numbers? Functions. [7, -pi] is the function from the set {1,2} to R mapping 1 to 7 and 2 to -pi. Arrows in space? Functions. The arrow pointing 7 units to the right and pi units down is the function from the plane to the plane mapping every point to the point 7 units right and pi units down from it.

Transpose please

The idea of orthogonality makes much more sense in the "functions-as-vectors" context than in the geometric one. Computing that the dot product = 0 for perpendicular (spatial) vectors is well and good, but it feels like computation - it's more demonstration than revelation. Ditto for the idea of changed basis vectors: it's quite obvious you can pick nearly-arbitrary bases, and the computational simplification employed by a change of basis in 3-space is often negligible. For those like me that don't think visually, there aren't inspiring conclusions to be found in 2- or 3-space.

In contrast, the power of theorems accessible through the orthogonality of Fourier and wavelet bases is awe-inspiring. When I later revisited orthogonality in the context of solution modes to the Bessel equation, I was in love all over again.

I watched this series before starting my Linear Algebra course because I wanted a head start, so as to make the course easier. Good thing I did, because you covered so much more than my course ever bothered explaining. We spent most of the lessons learning matrix multiplication and determinants and Gaussian elimination without even being explained what these things meant and why they worked the way they did. We only learned linear transformations on the very last lesson, and even then it was just "additivity and scaling", with no real depth. I get that the reason they did so is that generality is important, but still, it would have been nice to spend some time with concrete vectors in space before jumping straight to abstract, general concepts of vectors.
This is priceless.

I had some doubt regarding the representation of polynomials shown here. If we start making an analogy, we write our vector v as v = Ux, where U is a matrix of basis vectors, and x tells the combination of the basis. So, in the same way, when we have defined basis functions, shouldn't we write polynomial p as p = Ba,
B = [b0 b1 ......bn......upto infinity]
and every basis function,
bn(x) = [-infinity ...........x^n......infinity].T and a is [a0 a1.........an....a(infinity)]

So when we take a derivative of p= Ba, using matrix D, it should be Dp or DBa. This is what we do in the linear transformation of vectors. So it essentially should be the application of composite matrix (DB) on infinite constant vector a.
or Dp = DBa
In linear transformation, we are effectively moving our basis vectors, but the offset matrix here will not change matrix B. In fact, it does not act on B, but on a. Here, our offset matrix is applied on a, and therefore,
Dp = BDa

Here, we are not changing our basis vectors B. We are keeping them intact and manipulating constant vector first. This really make me spin around, but finally, I came to conclusion that both are possible.

If we go p = DBa approach, our derivative matrix D will simply be difference matrix not offset matrix. It will do numerical differentiation of every column of b and transform say x^2 into 2x for all the infinite x's.

DB = [Db0 Db1 Db2....Dbn....] --------------> [0 b0 2b1 3b2....]

Which is equivalent to result we get from applying the offset matrix to a.

I think of it as instead of changing basis vectors as we do in the matrix on vector operation, we keep basis vector same and change the combination. So instead of AUx, where A is a linear transformation and U is basis vector matrix, we use UBx here, and we change the combination x of basis vectors to give the same result.
This changes everything! My god I'm so thankful for these videos!

Linear Algebra review day6

What would the dot-product mean in the context of the (countably-infinite-dimensional) vector space of polynomials?
E.g. let P and Q be polynomials: P(x) = a + b*x + c*x^2 + ... + z*x^n; Q(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + ... + Z*x^n
Then the inner product (aka dot product) P.Q = aA + bB + cC + ... + zZ
but what does this (number, or some other element of a field) describe? When we are looking at the vector space R^2 or R^3, the inner product gives the squared-euclidean distance. So It has a tangible interpretation. But do all vector spaces have some tangible interpretation of their inner products?

As far as I'm concerned, when you talk about abstract vector spaces, you should explain clearly what abstract means, something that, I think, is easy to do. For example, suppose you're going down the street with a friend of yours. All of a sudden, you say "Look at that yellow car" and you say whatever you wanted to say about the car in question. Now, a car has many properties: it can be big or small, fast or slow, etc. But of all the properties it has, you asked your friend to focus on one of its properties - in this case, the colour of the car. And that, is abstraction: you have an object (or a bunch of objects) and you focus in one or part of the properties that the object(s) has(have). In the case of Linear Algebra, you start with the following objects: vectors, matrices, functions, etc. On each of these objects, two operations are defined: a sum and a product of those objects by a scalar. This operations have several properties: the sum of two vectors (or matrices, or functions, etc.) is yet again a vector; the sum is commutative, etc. Of all the properties that this objects have, you focus on only 8 of these properties. What you get is an abstraction - an abstract vector space; and, in the reverse sense, each of the examples given is a concrete realisation of this abstraction. The next thing one should ask is: why bother doing such an abstraction? There's a quick result that motivates and justifies powerfully such an idea: let v be a vector of a vector space V (in the generalized and abstract manner just discussed; that is, you're not longer focusing on any particular example, but, rather, you change your point view and focus only on properties); given the (abstracted) properties of any vector space, it follows easily that 0.v=0 (I won't go through the proof). What this example shows, is that, instead of proving such a result first, for vectors, then for matrices, then for functions, if you start seeing things from an abstract point of view, all the results proved in an abstract manner will obviously also be proved for any concrete case! Imagine that! That's very, very smart and it allows you to save a lot of time. It also allows one to see the real nature of these objects. Abstraction then, is something very powerful and completely justified.

The quote at the beginning does as much if not more good for the future of mathematics as the excellent video.  Thank you for acknowledging the need.  Alchemy was open to any hermit, but starting with Fermat, mathematics began more and more to be the purvey of bourgeois elites and nobles.  We thought every one might benefit, but along the way towers of intellectual power served to deny to humanity its birthright, and hold this beautiful knowledge behind a one way mirror of entitlement.  Any well-taught subject is understandable to most people.  The Internet is finally making mathematics accessible to everyone.  Yes, in plain English, mathematics is a good ole boys club.  There are tiny enclaves of geniuses clutching the scraps of their Riemann Hypothesis proof unwilling to explain their work to anyone for fear of ridicule, or the off possibility that someone else will get the glory.  There are many socialization problems among mathematicians which are never spoken about.  The whole field needs the light of modernity to break in and revolutionize both our understanding and our estimation of its importance.  Augsburger’s and other mood disorders run rampant among professors, and many students are put off by the inaccessible definitions and undesirable culture.  Though few will agree that that odd math professor who can’t get into her garage because she never takes out her garbage is actually mentally ill because she’s a genius, it might actually be time for the sake of education and the further progress of mathematics to have that discussion in all seriousness.

Wow. For the vector space of functions, all exponential functions multiplied by a constant are eigenfunctions. For k*e^x, the eigenvalue is 1 because taking the derivative doesn't change it. For another exponential function k*n^x, the eigenvalue for the derivative is ln(n) because taking the derivative multiplies it by ln(n), so each base n is like an infinite line of eigenvectors.

The second axiom follows from the last two:

(1+1)(w+z) = 1(w+z) + 1(w+z) = w + z + w + z

(1+1)(w+z) = (1+1)w + (1+1)z = w + w + z + z

Now add (-w) from the left and (-z) from the right and you get z + w = w + z.

Another interesting application of this idea is to linear ODEs. Say you have a system of n-order differential equations with p variables and m equations, such as

a_0*x_1 + a_1*d/dt*x_1 + ... + a_n*d^n/dt^n *x_1 + ... + b_0*x_p + b_1*d/dt*x_p + ... + b_n*d^n/dt^n * x_p = 0, and so forth.

You can then represent this system of equations as R(d/dt)*x = 0, where R(h) is a m-by-p matrix of polynomials (yes you can substitute the diff operator instead of h) and x is a vector (x_1(t) ... x_p(t)). A possible solution to this system of equations is the linear combination of eigenfunctions c*e^{a*t}*x, with 'a' being an unique root of the characteristic polynomial det(R), if R is square.

Can someone verify my thoughts or help me understand the application of linear algebra to my field of study better, if possible?

So in signal processing, we start with a linear time-invariant system. By using phasors (e^(jwt) where j = imaginary i, w = frequency in radians/second, and t as time) we are using e^jwt as a basis for some space that describes the magnitude, frequency and phase of the components of interest (voltage, current, speed, acceleration, etc) of an oscillatory system.
For describing these systems in the time domain we use differentiation, itself a linear operator. The peculiar property of the exponential function to output an scaled version of itself upon differentiation is what makes it a good choice for a basis. Suppose f = e^jwt, and we use f as an input to the differentiator (a system). The output will be y = jw*(e^jwt) = jw*f. This expresses the input as a scaled version of itself. So e^jwt is an eigenvector, the system (e.g. differentiator) is an eigenfunction, and the eigenvalue is jw.

So this is why eigenbasis are useful? The fact that the output can be described as some scaled version of the input?

Would a non-linear or time-variant system be like a matrix where eigenvalues don't exist? and if so, would there be some higher dimensional or imaginary solution (for example in the case of a matrix applying rotation) where eigenvalues don't really exist but you kind of make them exist in another space to make the math work.

If so, could we make descriptions of non-linear or time-invariant systems using the same process as a rotation matrix? In other words, coming up with some new basis function/vector to find the eigenvalue, thereby still describing the system easily using an eigenbasis?

One more insight into abstract vector spaces is that they're categorical.

This means that (for any dimension n) there is a vector space to which all other vector spaces (of dimension n) are isomorphic, and the usual n-dimensional spaces will do the trick.

So there is something fundamental about n-dimensional space after all.

These infinite matrices like the differential operator (henceforth called "Ad") have an interesting property.
With finite matrices A and B the concept of an inverse does not depend on the order. If A=B^-1, then B=A^-1.
This is not true for the differential operator matrix. If you multiply it with the Integral operator "Ai", then you get the identity matrix "I": Ad*Ai = I. But if you multiply them the other way around, you don't get the identity: Ai*Ad != I.
So the differential operator is the inverse of the integral operator but not vice versa (just like in normal calculus).

The word "interface" brought me total enlightenment. A vector can be thought of just like an interface in computer programming. The "IVector" interface definition contains all methods (axioms) that the classes (vector spaces) must implement. When dealing with instances of these classes (actual vectors), we can be sure that the eight rules apply to them and we don't need to know anything else.
